headline: Nike Reports Earnings This Week. How to Tell If Its Turnaround Is Working.
summary: The footwear powerhouse has struggled with rising inventories, increasing competition, and sluggish consumer demand in key regions.

headline: Nike earnings: Why its Q2 results are being watched so closely
summary: Wall Street is looking to Nike's (NKE) second fiscal quarter earnings results, scheduled for release on Thursday after market close. BMO Capital Markets managing director Simeon Siegel joined Morning Brief to preview his outlook on the results. Siegel noted that Nike is one of the world's largest consumer companies "dealing with a huge turnaround," and the new CEO Elliot Hill, who is leading this transformation, is relatively unknown to analysts. He emphasized that the upcoming earnings call will be the first opportunity for Wall Street to hear the strategic plan. "I think we have to accept this is going to take some time," Siegel said. "The trade here is do you want to believe in hope or are you going to get held down by numbers? And I think the reality is for a company like Nike, hope can be powerful." Regarding Elliot Hill, Siegel states: "I think the guy who's been there since an intern, who's risen through this entire process of the business, is probably the perfect person to bring the business back to what it needs to be." However, he cautioned, "But I don't know that this should be revolutionary. I don't know that you and I want to wake up next year and see a dramatically different Nike than the one we know." To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief here. This post was written by Angel Smith

headline: Nike price target lowered to $92 from $95 at Wells Fargo
summary: Wells Fargo analyst Ike Boruchow lowered the firm’s price target on Nike (NKE) to $92 from $95 and keeps an Overweight rating on the shares as the firm is cutting numbers below Street. Wells believes Nike remains challenged through Q2. Direct-to-consumer reads are weak, FX headwinds have grown, and supplier checks suggest that current “Franchise Management” efforts will be extended into 2025. Published first on TheFly – the ultimate source for real-time, market-moving breaking financial news. Tr
